In South Australia, police have been accused of charging their alleged victims instead, to stop their allegations being properly investigated.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Julian Assange will fight to overturn a UK High Court ruling that rejected his appeal against extradition to the United States. The WikiLeaks founder is wanted in the US for espionage, where he faces 18 charges related to publishing of tens of thousands of military and diplomatic documents. The 51-year-old Australian lodged an appeal in Britain's High Court last year after the UK government signed an order authorising his extradition to the US. The court this week rejected his appeal in a three-page written decision from Justice Jonathan Swift. In a statement on Twitter, Assange's wife Stella says her husband will contest the ruling – which will be his last legal option in the UK in his long-running legal saga. Assange has been held in Belmarsh prison for more than four years.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Julian Assange to fight UK High Court decision against his extradition to the US

props.alt: Julian Assange, wearing glasses, sits in prison van

children.content: Julian Assange has been held in London's Belmarsh prison since 2019
(Reuters: Simon Dawson)
Julian Assange
will fight to overturn a UK High Court ruling
that rejected his appeal against extradition to the United States.
The WikiLeaks founder is wanted in the US for espionage, where he faces
18 charges related
to publishing of tens of thousands of military and diplomatic documents
The 51-year-old Australian lodged an appeal in Britain's High Court last year after the UK government signed an order authorising
his extradition to the US
The court this week rejected his appeal in a three-page written decision from Justice Jonathan Swift.
In a statement on Twitter, Assange's wife Stella says her husband will contest the ruling – which will be his last legal option in the UK in his long-running legal saga.
Assange has been held in Belmarsh prison for more than four years.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The largest ruby in the world to come to auction has set a new record at Sotheby's New York, selling for $US34.8 million ($52 million). The ruby is known as Estrela de Fura 55.22, which means Star of Fura in Portuguese. "It is from Mozambique, which is also one of the new and more popular origins that we see for rubies, apart from the more traditional and the classic Burmese pieces," says Uni Kim, a jewelry specialist at Sotheby's Hong Kong. The ruby was found last July. "It is one of the biggest and largest gem-quality ruby that we have ever seen," Kim says. "The colour and the saturation, the clarity together with you know everything that comes together with the ruby, it's just a very fantastic and beautiful piece." The previous world record for a ruby sold at auction was set in May 2015 by a 25.59-carat Burmese stone called Sunrise Ruby that fetched $45 million at Sotheby's in Geneva.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: World's largest ruby sells at auction for a record price

props.alt: An Asian woman with white gloves holds a red ruby ring

"It is one of the biggest and largest gem-quality ruby that we have ever seen," Kim says.
"The colour and the saturation, the clarity together with you know everything that comes together with the ruby, it's just a very fantastic and beautiful piece."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Victoria's Chief Health Officer Brett Sutton is stepping down from his position after four years in a role that saw him become one of the faces of the state's COVID-19 pandemic response. Sutton is leaving to take up a new position as Director of Health and Biosecurity at CSIRO. Sutton first joined the Department of Health in 2011, before being appointed chief health officer in 2019. Alongside Premier Daniel Andrews, he became a daily feature of Victoria’s COVID-19 response, delivering daily case numbers in televised media conferences. The 53-year-old Melbourne native spent a decade working in hospital emergency departments before stints overseas to Afghanistan and Ethiopia. You can keep reading this story here:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Brett Sutton quits as Victoria's Chief Health Officer

featuredLink.title: Victoria's chief health officer Brett Sutton resigns after stint as face of COVID-19 response

props.alt: A silver-haired middle-aged man in blue blazer speaks at news conference

children.content: Brett Sutton with Premier Daniel Andrews in 2020
(AAP: Michael Dodge)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: In news that will surprise just about no one, especially if you're trying to get a loan at the moment, the 12 interest rate hikes by the Reserve Bank have had a massive impact on how much people can borrow. According to RateCity, the average family’s maximum borrowing capacity has shrunk by $247,700 compared to April last year, once the latest hike takes effect. The 'average' RateCity has used is a family of four, with one parent working full time, one working part time, on a combined annual income of $143,221 before tax — and that obviously doesn't account of individuals' particular circumstances. For a single person earning the average wage, with no debts, no dependents and minimal expenses, the maximum amount they can borrow from the bank will have dropped by $180,000 in the last 14 months. "People on the hunt for a new home have been dealing with a market that's defying gravity, on a budget that gets smaller by the month," said RateCity research director Sally Tindall. "Once this latest cash rate decision takes effect, the big banks' ongoing variable rates are likely to be over 6 per cent, which means borrowers will soon be stress tested at rates of over 9 per cent. " That's a staggering hurdle to clear, particularly for first home buyers with limited savings and smaller incomes. "If prices don't come down, potential first home buyers could end up sitting on the sidelines altogether, unless they can get a sizeable leg up from their family." It's also going to impact borrowers trying to refinance, as they'll be assessed on their ability to repay on the same stress-tested rates over 9 per cent — putting more people into the 'mortgage prisoner' camp, particularly those with newer or lower equity loans.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Borrowing power shrinks by nearly $250k: RateCity

children.content: In news that will surprise just about no one, especially if you're trying to get a loan at the moment,
the 12 interest rate hikes by the Reserve Bank have had a massive impact on how much people can borrow

compared to April last year, once the latest hike takes effect.

The 'average' RateCity has used is a family of four, with one parent working full time, one working part time, on a combined annual income of $143,221 before tax — and that obviously doesn't account of individuals' particular circumstances.
For
a single person earning the average wage
, with no debts, no dependents and minimal expenses,
the maximum amount they can borrow
from the bank will have
dropped by $180,000
in the last 14 months.
"People on the hunt for a new home have been dealing with a market that's defying gravity, on a budget that gets smaller by the month," said RateCity research director Sally Tindall.

"Once this latest cash rate decision takes effect, the big banks' ongoing variable rates are likely to be over 6 per cent, which means borrowers will soon be stress tested at rates of over 9 per cent.
That's a staggering hurdle to clear, particularly for first home buyers
with limited savings and smaller incomes.
"If prices don't come down, potential first home buyers could end up sitting on the sidelines altogether, unless they can get a sizeable leg up from their family."

It's also going to impact borrowers trying to refinance, as they'll be assessed on their ability to repay on the same stress-tested rates over 9 per cent — putting more people into the 'mortgage prisoner' camp, particularly those with newer or lower equity loans.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: It's nearly tax time, but as you think about prepping your return you might be surprised to learn the following: 66 people earned more than $1 million and paid no income tax in 2020-21, according to newly released figures by the Australian Taxation Office (ATO). Analysis of ATO data by the Australia Institute shows those people earned an average of $14.5 million. One of the deductions they claimed was using a tax agent to manage their affairs, which is an allowable write-off — they paid on average a hefty $219,000 to their accountants. You can read the full piece from Kate Ainsworth here:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: The 66 millionaires who paid no income tax

featuredLink.title: 66 people earned an average of $14.5 million in 2020-21. None of them paid a cent in tax to the ATO

, according to newly released figures by the Australian Taxation Office (ATO).
Analysis of ATO data by the Australia Institute shows those people earned an average of $14.5 million.
One of the deductions they claimed was using a tax agent to manage their affairs, which is an allowable write-off — they paid on average a hefty $219,000 to their accountants.
You can read the full piece from Kate Ainsworth here:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Good morning and happy Friday! Stephanie Chalmers here to take you through the day, and it's looking set to be a pretty positive start to the session with futures pointing higher. It follows some decent gains on Wall Street, particularly for tech stocks. Amazon rose 2.5%, while Netflix ended up 2.4%. Electric carmaker Tesla also did well, rising 4.6%. The US dollar came under some pressure as oil prices slumped, and some data on weekly jobless claims was worse than expected, which helped the Aussie dollar above 67 US cents. In Europe, markets were mostly higher but eurozone economic growth was revised lower for the first quarter, down 0.1 per cent. And since that's the second quarter of economic contraction in a row, that means a 'technical recession'. It's been a pretty massive week, with the Reserve Bank raising rates for a 12th time and Australia's economic growth slowing, so stick with us, ahead of what's a long weekend in some states (the ASX will be closed on Monday).
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX eyes gains after Wall Street rallies
